Project Description  The Project will support the Government’s development goals by 
supporting improvements in the quality of secondary education 
through extensive support for teacher education for general upper 
secondary and professional secondary education.  
   
Rationale  The  Government  strongly  emphasizes  the  need  to  expand 
secondary  education,  particularly  professional  secondary  (PS) 
education. It recognizes that expansion must be accompanied by 
improvements in quality if the education system is to meet the 
country’s  needs  for  a  skilled  and  well-qualified  labor  force. 
Enrollment  projections  indicate  significant  rates  of  growth  until 
2010.  
   
Impact and Outcome  The  Project’s  goal  is  to  help  reduce  poverty  in  Viet  Nam  by 
improving the quality of upper secondary (US) education and PS, 
thereby producing a better qualified and more productive work 
force. The project outcomes will be (i) improved quality of US and 
PS  preservice  and  in-service  teacher  training;  (ii)  expanded 
access  for ethnic minorities, particularly women, to US and PS 
teacher  development;  (iii)  strengthened  capacity  for  planning, 
management, and delivery of teacher training for US and PS; and 
(iv)  improved  facilities  to  strengthen  instructional  capability  in 
teacher training institutes. The Project will (i) enhance access and 
equity, training quality, efficiency, and management; (ii) sponsor a 
national teacher development system to integrate preservice and 
in-service training; and (iii) provide targeted support to (a) teacher 
training  institutes  (TTIs)  in  ethnic  minority  areas;  (b)  ethnic 
minority students, particularly women; and (c) TTIs in areas with 
rapid economic growth. 
   
Project Investment Plan  The investment cost of the Project is estimated at $43.18 million 
equivalent, including taxes and duties.

accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (April 2006, as

anticorruption.

492  person-months  of  national  consulting  will  be  provided  in

(April  2006,  as  amended  from  time  to  time).  The  consulting

Project Benefits and  The Project will have substantial benefits for the education sector, 
Beneficiaries  in particular secondary education, through systemic improvements 
for design, delivery, and management of teacher development for 
US and PS. 
 
The direct beneficiaries of the Project will be (i) current and future 
US and PS teachers who will have continuing opportunities to 
improve  their  professional  competencies  through  improved 
preservice  and  in-service  training  programs;  and  (ii)  ethnic 
minority groups, particularly women, who will have greater access 
to  quality  teacher  training  programs  through  provision  of 
scholarships, dormitories, and enhanced facilities in TTIs serving 
ethnic minority areas. The project-initiated improvement in their 
professional development will better ensure that all US and PS 
students are provided with a school experience that contributes to 
life choices, to reduction of poverty through greater employability, 
and to the achievement of national economic development goals 
through a better qualified work force. The indirect beneficiaries will 
be current and future US and PS students who will benefit from 
instruction from a better qualified teaching force. 
   
Risks and Assumptions  The major project risk emanates from the number of institutions to 
be supported by the Project and the combination of hardware and 
software  inputs.  This  will  require  considerable  management 
capacity  within  the  project  management  unit  to  ensure  project 
inputs within the time lines and resources outlined. The Project 
mitigates this risk by requiring establishment of coordination and 
oversight  committees  within  the  project  management  unit  and 
each  beneficiary  TTI  to  monitor  progress  and  take  timely 
measures to address delays.  
 
Any faltering of commitment to review policy issues related to

impact  policy  formulation.  The  Government  has  expressed  its 
support for a comprehensive policy framework. The Project will 
support  this  policy  framework  with  an  agreed  implementation 
framework.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to  the  Socialist  Republic  of  Viet Nam  for  the  Upper  Secondary  and  Professional  Teacher 
Development Project. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
II.   RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
A.   Performance Indicators and Analysis 
2.  Viet  Nam  has  made  significant  progress  in  improving  access  to  education,  having 
achieved a net enrollment ratio (NER) in 2005 of 94% for primary education and 51% for 
secondary (a significant increase for secondary from 18.7% in 1993). Annual enrollment in 
upper secondary (US) education over the past 9 years increased by an average of 12.9%, while 
the corresponding increase in the vocationally oriented professional secondary (PS) education 
was  11%.  The  Government  projects  that  average  annual  increases  in  US  enrollment  will 
gradually decline from 14.6% in 2005 to 4.8% in 2010. However, the Government expects 
participation in US by 2010 will be 60%, exceeding its target of 50%. PS enrollment increases 
are expected to rise from an annual rate of 4.9% in 2005 to 14.6% in 2010, creating ambitious 
teacher expansion targets. Together, both subsectors will require approximately 58,000 more 
teachers until 2010—an increase of 43.9% excluding the needs arising from attrition rates 
notionally set at 5% per annum. This large increase will strain the ability of teacher training 
institutes (TTIs) to supply the teachers required if current student-teacher ratios are to continue. 
If lower ratios are to be realized to enhance student learning, demand for additional teachers will 
be even higher.  
3.  The challenge is not only to increase the number of trained teachers but also to enhance 
the quality of training. The Government also recognizes the need to improve classroom teaching 
methodologies to engender in future students the knowledge and creative skills required to 
contribute  to  the  achievement  of  declared  national  development  goals.  This  will  require 
improving  TTIs’  capacity  to  modernize  staff  training  techniques.  Further,  accreditation 
procedures need to be established for training institutions to ensure standardization and quality 
of the training curriculum. Finally, progressive consistency is needed between preservice and in-
service training.  
4.  Viet Nam’s economy is growing faster than that of all other Southeast Asian countries. 
The Government places significant emphasis on expanding the reach of and improving the 
quality of education to sustain the pace of economic growth and maintain competitiveness. 
Since primary education is almost universal, the secondary education sector is particularly 
positioned for rapid expansion.  
 
B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
5.  As the economy continues to expand, school graduates need to be better equipped with 
the wide range of problem-solving and research skills that emerging knowledge industries 
require. In response, a new curriculum has been developed for US that changes pedagogy from 
reliance on passive learning to an emphasis on student-centered learning that fosters curiosity 
and creativity. Teachers in schools need to be retrained in the new pedagogy, including the use 
of information technology; and those training to be teachers need to achieve a reconstructed 
view  of  teaching.  To  acquire  these  new  skills,  trainee  teachers  need  to  experience  them 
throughout their training, so that they discover the benefits of enquiry-based learning and its

2   
application to personal development and employability. This will require TTI staff to update their 
own teaching methods to model the best teaching styles, including more informed monitoring 
and assessment techniques to ensure the effectiveness and quality of their trainees’ learning. 
The use of information technology needs to be an integral part of teacher training programs, as 
students will be working in an increasingly rich information technology environment throughout 
their careers. A summary of the key issues follows.  
1.  Access 
6.  Even though significant progress has been made in improving access to education, the 
NER for US is still low at approximately 51%. Ethnic minority students are underrepresented at 
9.4%  of  total  enrollment.  Even  though  enrollment  rates  of  ethnic  minority  students  are 
increasing,  they  are  still  below  those  of  the  general  population.  Poverty  is  a  significant 
determinant of disadvantage with a NER of 17.1% for the poorest compared with 67.2% for the 
richest.1 Urban–rural enrollment disparities are significant with 59.2% of students enrolled in 
urban areas against 37.7% in rural areas. Rural areas also have significantly lower school 
completion  rates.  For  some  ethnic  minority  groups,  particularly  in  remote  rural  areas, 
attendance at school is far below other groups; and poverty among ethnic minority groups is 
declining at a lower rate than in the general population. Overall labor force participation rates 
are lower for women, although they are well represented in the teaching force. Of all US 
teachers,  approximately  56.1%  are  women  and  3.5%  are  from  ethnic  minorities.  Women 
represent 45% of PS teachers; corresponding data for ethnic minority representation is not 
available.  
7.  The remote mountain  areas continue to have difficulty attracting qualified teachers. 
Residents have poor access to teaching as a career, and teachers in isolated areas have poor 
access to in-service support. Increased support is needed to improve access to teacher training 
programs  for  students  from  ethnic  minorities  and  people  from  remote  rural  areas;  and  to 
improve the quality of teacher education programs, both preservice and in-service, so that local 
teachers have the opportunity to develop professional competencies and pedagogical skills. 
2.  Quality 
 
8.  Curriculum and Assessment. While new curriculum standards have been developed 
for primary and lower secondary teacher training courses, no corresponding improvements have 
been  introduced  for  either  US  or PS  teacher  training.  Training  improvements  are  urgently 
needed to support the new school curriculum and model pedagogy that encourages students to 
explore complex ideas and use knowledge in creative, problem-solving ways.  
 
9.  Teacher  Quality.  Seventeen  percent  of  PS  teachers  are  underqualified.  Teacher 
training courses, in general, tend to be based on traditional passive approaches to learning—in 
stark contrast to the Government’s stated policy of significantly improving current classroom 
practice by shifting from passive to active learning through more creative and student-centered 
pedagogy, including the use of information technology. 
 
10.  In-service support for teachers is needed to ensure that teachers’ professional practice 
remains up-to-date and relevant. This will require strong links between preservice and in-service 
training courses to ensure that teacher education is a consistent, logical, career-long process. 
Induction programs need to be developed to support teachers in their first year of teaching as

Such  induction  programs  will  help  improve  the  performance  of  beginner  teachers,  and—
consistent with international practice—help retain young teachers within the profession. 
 
  3.  Upper Secondary and Professional Secondary Education 
 
11.  The final phase of secondary education is divided into two subsectors. US provides 
general education with a focus on higher education, while PS has a major focus on technical 
and vocational training. US is the much larger of the two subsectors. In 2005 it accounted for 
85.7% of schools, 88.4% of teachers, and 85.7% of students. It has lower student-teacher ratios 
of 26.29:1 compared with 33.47:1 for PS. While both subsectors have experienced similar 
enrollment growth over the past 5 years, the PS growth rates for teachers and number of 
schools  are  much  lower.  The  Government’s  recent  enrollment  projections  for  2005–2010 
indicate an average growth rate of 8% for US and 15% for PS. Statistics also indicate that 
among regions student-teacher ratios for US are very similar, but vary considerably for PS. The 
Mekong River Delta and the South East regions appear to be disadvantaged, as they have 
considerably  higher  ratios  than  elsewhere.  Higher  demand  for  vocational  education  as 
evidenced by rapidly increasing enrollment and government's emphasis on vocational education 
reflect  the  human  resource  needs  of  a  rapidly  growing  economy.  A  detailed  sector  and 
subsector analysis is in Appendix 2. 
 
12.  Currently, responsibility for preservice teacher training is dispersed among a wide range 
of institutions with an uneven geographic distribution. Despite the large number of institutions 
providing preservice training, capacity to meet projected demand is likely to be stretched and 
some areas have unmet demand in some subjects. Pedagogy and the quality of all TTI courses 
need to be improved through appropriate accreditation procedures to ensure a high standard of 
entry competencies of all new teachers.  
 
  4.  Management and Institutional Capacity 
 
13.  The  Ministry  of  Education  and  Training  (MOET)  has  a  complex  structure  under  a 
minister  of  education  and  training,  supported  by  six  vice  ministers  responsible for  various 
departments within the education portfolio (Supplementary Appendix A). This complexity can 
create  both  policy  and  data  collection  difficulties,  with  various  departments  communicating 
inadequately with one another. At the same time, decentralization is occurring, albeit gradually. 
Local departments of education and training (DOETs) are being given greater authority, as 
school principals. Within the teacher training sector, MOET is responsible for the management 
of preservice training, while the DOETs play a stronger role in in-service training. MOET has 
limited capacity to provide accurate and timely information, or to analyze trends to better plan 
future policies and programs. This constrains its ability to ensure quality of planning associated 
with teacher training. Although MOET has exhibited strong commitment to education, it needs 
support  to  develop  a  policy  and  quality  assurance  framework  for  US  and  PS  teacher 
development; and an information management system that will allow it to plan and manage the 
training and career development of the large teaching force. The Project will provide capacity-
building support for developing a comprehensive policy framework for teacher education; for an 
accreditation process for training courses; and a teacher information management system, 
including professional profiles of teachers.

4   
  5.  Government Policies 
 
14.  The Government accords very high priority to education as a tool for achieving its 
national  development  goals.  The  Government’s  Education  Development  Strategic  Plan  for 
2001–2010 outlines the major educational reforms. The Government has also committed that 
within the education sector it will increase support to PS to improve the quality and number of 
technical workers. This policy responds to a perceived need to better match human capital 
development with industry needs. In May 2005, the minister of education and training released a 
document identifying 59 areas for improvement—at least half are relevant to the Project.2 The 
Project  is  consistent  with  the  Government’s  educational  goals,  and  proposes  activities  to 
support relevant areas for improvement that cover both preservice and in-service education; 
and include improved pedagogy, accreditation, contemporary knowledge and skills, and an 
increased focus on PS. The Government has matched its stated commitment to education with 
higher budgetary allocations. Education’s share as a percentage of gross domestic product 
increased  from  3.5%  in  1996  to  4.6%  in  2004.  However,  despite  increasing  budgetary 
allocations, rapid expansion at higher levels of education, particularly secondary education, will 
continue to strain available resources. Expansion occurs at the expense of quality, unless 
resources are specifically targeted to quality enhancement interventions.  
 
  6.  Education Sector Strategy of the Asian Development Bank 
 
15.  The vision for education of the Asian Development Bank (ADB), as stated in its policy 
document  Education  (2002),  is  that  all  children  and  adults  will  have  equitable  access  to 
education of sufficient quality to empower them to break out of the poverty cycle, improve their 
quality  of  life,  and  participate  effectively  in  national  development.  ADB’s  poverty  reduction 
strategy also calls for support for provision of basic services, including education, as a key 
poverty reduction measure.  
 
16.  ADB’s strategy for the education sector in Viet Nam has evolved to emphasize the 
consolidation of investments made during past projects and to build upon them toward holistic 
planning  and  management  for  the  education  sector.  The  process  began  under  the  ADB- 
financed Primary Education Development Project. It was then extended through the Lower 
Secondary Education Development Project, including the lower secondary Teacher Training 
Project,  which  created  infrastructure  for  teacher  training  and  will  be  strengthened  and 
consolidated under the ongoing Upper Secondary Education Development Project. The Upper 
Secondary and Professional Teacher Development Project will provide critical complementary 
support  to  past  and  ongoing  initiatives  in  secondary  education  by  improving  teacher 
competencies, an area recognized to be the key to improving education quality. Therefore, the 
Project complements ADB’s support for US, where ADB is the lead funding agency. The Project 
is designed to support ADB’s strategy of taking a longer term perspective of sector development 
and committing to a series of interventions that focus on high-priority goals and measurable 
targets within a sector policy framework. ADB assistance to the education sector in Viet Nam is 
consistent with the Government’s priorities of improving access to and quality of secondary 
education.  The  Project  supports  the  targets  of  the  Government’s  Education  Development 
Strategic  Plan  for  2001–2010  of  increasing  enrollment  in  US  and  PS  through  selective 
expansion of physical facilities in selected TTIs; and supporting poverty reduction through a

7.  External Assistance 
 
17.  External assistance to Viet Nam reached $2 billion in 2003, placing Viet Nam among the 
top 10 recipient countries. Education’s share of external assistance ranges from 8.5% to 10%. 
Within education expenditures, external assistance will continue to play an important role in 
education  development.  ADB  is  the  lead  funding  agency  in  the  education  sector  having 
supported five projects for lower and upper secondary education since 1999. The World Bank is 
the other major funding agency with support concentrated on basic and higher education. Other 
funding  agencies  supporting  the  education  sector  include  the  European  Union,  France, 
Germany,  Japan,  Netherlands  and  the  United  Kingdom  (Appendix  3).  To  increase  the 
effectiveness of external assistance, and given the level of development of the education sector, 
some funding agencies are piloting provision of output-based budgetary support for specific 
government initiatives for primary education. This may be a precursor to broader program-
based lending or may signal a shift to a mixed modality sector-wide approach. ADB is currently 
providing technical assistance to undertake a comprehensive assessment for possible program 
assistance. However, the needs for teacher training for US and PS require targeted attention, 
particularly  for  system-wide  curriculum  and  pedagogical  reform.  The  Project  provides  this 
support and will help prepare this subsector to be better equipped to benefit from evolving 
sector funding modalities. 
  8.  Lessons  
 
18.  Extensive funding agency support to the education sector in Viet Nam, and ADB’s own 
experience provide important lessons for maximizing the benefits of this Project and, in a few 
cases, for avoiding certain risks. While the benefits found are consistent with those outlined 
within the Project, the lessons relevant for the current Project are (i) overall project management 
quality is weak and needs to be strengthened so that project activities are undertaken in a timely 
manner, and clear accountability guidelines need to be established and followed; (ii) the focus of 
technical assistance should be sharpened for building capacity of education staff and experts; 
(iii) management ability for education and training needs strengthening; (iv) decision making 
processes are slow; (v) staff within project management units change frequently; and (vi) project 
design should be clear (Supplementary Appendix B). 
 
19.  Project  preparation  was  guided  by  the  Government’s  education  policies,  in-depth 
situation  analysis,  and  a  review  of  lessons  identified  from  experience.  The  Project  places 
significant emphasis on (i) ensuring policy coherence for teacher development; (ii) strengthening 
capacity of education staff and experts for improved planning, management, and delivery of 
teacher education; and (iii) improving access for ethnic minorities. The Project has detailed 
design with all activities clearly described; it provides for strengthened coordination by the 
project authorities and the institutions responsible for delivery of project outputs. In addition, the 
Project provides for an international expert to be located within the project management unit 
(PMU) to advise on project implementation in addition to other substantive tasks.

III.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
20.  The goal of the Project is to help reduce poverty in Viet Nam by improving the quality of 
US and PS, thereby producing a better qualified and more productive work force. The outcomes 
of the Project will be (i) improved quality of US and PS preservice and in-service teacher 
training; (ii) expanded access for ethnic minorities, particularly women, to US and PS teacher 
development; (iii) strengthened capacity for planning, management, and delivery of teacher 
training for US and PS; and (iv) improved facilities to strengthen instructional capability in the 
TTIs. The Project will enhance access and equity, training quality, efficiency, and management. 
It will help strengthen the national teacher development system to integrate preservice and in-
service training. The Project will provide targeted support to (i) TTIs in ethnic minority areas; (ii) 
ethnic minority students, particularly women; and (iii) TTIs in areas of high enrollment and rapid 
economic growth.  
B.   Outputs 
1.  Enhance Quality of US and PS Preservice and In-Service Teacher Training  
21.  Improvement in the quality of teaching is essential for producing a more capable work 
force. Education must meet the needs of a rapidly growing economy for competent problem-
solvers who are imaginative, adaptable, and creative. To accomplish this, the changing skills 
mix required of school graduates must be reflected in the way teachers are trained. This 
requires new approaches, as most teachers continue to teach in traditional ways in which they 
them selves were taught. The inputs integral to this component have been placed under two 
major  headings—Preservice  Teacher  Training  and  In-service  Teacher  Training—and  are 
detailed below:  
 
a.  Preservice Teacher Training 
22.  Alignment of the Teacher-Training Curriculum with the School Curriculum. MOET 
will develop guidelines, develop a training curriculum framework and to review current training 
courses to reflect the changes in the school curriculum. The guidelines will establish clear 
requirements  for  review  to  determine  relevance  of  courses,  and  examine  the  need  for 
introduction  of  new  courses,  especially  for  PS  education,  where  it  is  essential  that  all 
professional school subjects be covered by current TTI courses and where the employment 
community likely to absorb PS graduates will be given an opportunity to contribute curriculum 
ideas. Selected TTIs will be commissioned to develop specific course outlines for all subject 
amendments and for new subjects. 
 
23.  Improve  Content  and  Methodology  of  Training  Programs.  The content  and  the 
pedagogy of courses will be improved to meet established accreditation criteria. To improve 
pedagogy, 20 6-month fellowships will be provided for staff to develop, trial, and document the 
effectiveness of new approaches to teaching, learning, and assessment. These fellowships will 
also explore increased use of information technology in course design and delivery, and support 
an inclusive curriculum to address issues of ethnic minorities and gender. A common theme in 
the  fellowships  will  be  the  development  of  more  active,  inclusive,  and  problem-solving 
approaches to teacher training. To develop new curriculum content, pedagogical guidelines, and 
contact  teaching  requirements  for  20  pedagogical  courses,  MOET  will  contract  adequate

7 
qualified  personnel  to  develop  the  20  courses  which  are  consistent  with  the  guidelines 
developed and issued by MOET. 
 
24.  Provide Induction Program for Beginner Teachers. Internationally, the first year of 
teaching is seen as a bridge between initial training and full registration. Many skills, attitudes, 
and approaches to teaching are formed during the teachers’ first year, including decisions on 
whether their career will be in teaching or elsewhere. The Project will introduce a supportive 
induction program for beginner teachers—to be conducted by DOETs and school principals—to 
retain them in the teaching force, habituate them to high classroom standards, and induce self-
confidence.  
 
25.  Enhance  Use  of  Information  Technology  in  Preservice  Programs.  Accreditation 
criteria  for  training  courses  will  require  that,  where  appropriate,  information  technology 
applications be incorporated in course design. As part of training in accreditation standards, TTI 
staff will be assisted to use information technology applications within training programs. Each 
TTI will train all first-year teacher trainees in Microsoft Word, Microsoft Excel, and Microsoft 
PowerPoint, etc., so that they use these skills throughout their 4 years of training. This will 
ensure that all teachers are familiar with information technology and can increasingly use it to 
plan and evaluate their own and their students’ performance.  
 
26.  Developing TTIs to serve as Lead Universities. Five TTIs will be provided support to 
serve as lead universities (LUs) and to develop professional partnerships with leading overseas 
universities. Consultants from the overseas universities will work with LU faculty for a total of 12 
months in the LUs, helping design and implement new approaches to teacher training, including 
assessment of outcomes. As part of the training program, a faculty member from each LU will 
spend three months at the counterpart overseas university, observing teacher-training programs 
in action. Through this process, it is expected that the best of international practice will be 
embedded in teacher training programs in Viet Nam, resulting in new pedagogical approaches 
being  adopted  by  teachers.  While  this  process  will  improve  course  design  and  teaching 
methodologies within the LUs, each LU will, in turn, provide support to other TTIs by conducting 
training programs for staff and developing an improved curriculum. LUs need improved facilities 
and equipment to provide better quality of teaching with improved pedagogy. Under the Project, 
each LU will receive support for upgrading facilities and for additional key equipment. LU staff 
will  also  receive  training  in  the  use  (and  maintenance)  of  enhanced  facilities  for  optimal 
improvements in teaching methods.  
 
27.  This component will have the following outputs: (i) 5,750 TTI lecturers will benefit from 
43 conferences and workshops provided to outline the new curriculum and approaches to 
teaching;  (ii)  MOET  will  issue  new  curriculum  guidelines  and  three  conferences  will  be 
organized to cover 300 key TTIs across the country to familiarize them with the guidelines; (iii) 
20 pedagogical courses will be developed conforming to new MOET guidelines; (iv) a new 
approach  for  supporting  first-year  teachers  will  be  developed  and  included  in  the  training 
programs provided for DOET staff and principals; (v) following a series of small workshops to

industry-accredited information technology training; and (vi) five TTIs will receive upgraded 
facilities, equipment and staff fellowships for overseas training.

30.  Develop Improved Training Programs for Teachers Working in US and PS Who Do

The pressure on the TTIs to meet this projected demand is high. The Project will support six 
TTIs located in predominantly ethnic minority areas that cater significantly to students from

3.  Strengthen Capacity for Planning, Management, and Delivery of Teacher 
Training for US and PS 
 
37.  Develop a Comprehensive Framework for Teacher Development. Existing policies 
and procedures for teacher management and assessment systems need to be reviewed to 
ensure that all aspects of teacher development, from initial selection and training to career-long 
in-service  training,  are  coordinated  and  complementary.  Currently,  the  policies  for  teacher 
development are disparate and no comprehensive teacher development plan is in place. The 
Project will help MOET review policies related to teacher education; and clarify, consolidate, and 
modify these as necessary. Following the review, a comprehensive framework for teacher 
education will be developed, supported by an implementation road map, which will address 
issues  of  preservice  qualifications,  recruitment,  deployment,  in-service  training,  career 
development, etc.  
38.  Ensure Quality Assurance through Accreditation of Training Programs. A major 
approach to strengthening the quality of teacher training is through accreditation of all TTI 
courses. The Accreditation Board established to accredit all higher education courses has only 
involved one TTI so far. The Project will strengthen the capacity of the Accreditation Board to 
expedite accreditation processes so that all TTI courses offered for US and PS teacher training 
are accredited by content, design, time allocated, pedagogical implications, assessment, and 
staff development. Only TTIs conducting accredited courses will be recognized in terms of 
providing qualified teachers. This is necessary to reduce unacceptable differences in the quality 
of training provided. Specifically, the Project will strengthen capacity within the Accreditation 
Board to accredit at least 10 TTI courses each year. MOET capacity will be strengthened to 
develop  the  criteria  and  standards,  as  well  as  assistance  with,  the  initial  accreditation  of 
preservice and in-service courses. An intensive training program will be conducted to assist

TTIs in redesigning their courses to meet accreditation requirements. Through a process of 
regular  reaccreditation,  courses  will  be  adapted  to  accommodate  new  knowledge  and 
approaches to teaching. To ensure course relevance to national and industry needs, the review 
and development of accreditation criteria and processes will be undertaken in consultation with 
stakeholders, including industry representatives.  
 
39.  Strengthen Capacity for Education Planning and Management. MOET’s ability for 
effective  planning  and  management  of  education  is  constrained  by  inadequate  information 
systems that are not able to provide accurate and recent data to allow analysis of trends and 
effective  planning.  More  appropriate  and  sophisticated  databases  (segregated  by  gender, 
ethnicity, location, etc. are needed to ensure quality, comprehensiveness, and consistency. The 
Project will (i) strengthen capacity by training MOET staff on data collection and analysis; (ii) 
strengthen the education management information system (EMIS); and (iii) develop a teacher 
management information system (TMIS) (Appendix 4). Activities include the following: 
 
(i)  Train  MOET  staff  on  data  analysis.  The  capacity  of  MOET  staff  will  be 
strengthened for collecting and analyzing data to monitor emerging national and 
international trends, and provide MOET with policy options and advice. 
(ii)  Strengthen  the  EMIS.  With  the  development  of  expanded  and  improved 
databases, a better data management system and procedures are needed. To 
undertake this task, an integrated computer-based system will connect all DOET 
offices and 31 TTIs with MOET to enable data collection and analysis, including 
reporting against relevant performance indicators. This will allow current human 
resource management systems to be integrated, facilitating improved human 
resource processes.  
(iii)  Develop  a  TMIS. While the annual statistical digest contains much valuable 
information, detailed information specific to US and PS teacher preservice and 
in-service training is more difficult to find and is located across a number of 
departments.  By  creating  a  TMIS,  relevant  and  rich  data  will  be  readily 
accessible. An improved interactive website with sufficient connectivity among all 
31 TTI sites and MOET and DOET offices will be established to allow for data 
collection and analysis. TTI staff will receive training to manage the database. 
 
40.  Develop Teacher Profiles for Enhancing Teacher Performance. Education systems 
are recognizing the centrality of teacher performance in achieving high-quality outcomes for 
students. To better develop teacher effectiveness, a trend is to develop teacher profiles or 
standards that identify what teachers need to know and be able to do in order to teach more 
effectively. This method is being piloted under the World Bank’s Primary Teacher Development 
Project to reward excellence and identify the professional development needs of teachers. The 
Project will build upon this pilot and extend it to US and PS teachers. Profiles will outline four 
levels of performance: beginner teacher, teacher, key teacher, and senior teacher to cover three 
key areas: knowledge, skills, and attributes required to be highly effective teachers. These 
profiles will be developed and piloted, with stakeholder consultations, in the nine provinces 
where the beneficiary TTIs are located. The profiles will form the basis of teacher reviews and 
be used to determine the relative effectiveness of teachers. This will also facilitate the planning 
of appropriate in-service support for all teachers. The development of the profiles will result in 
improved quality assurance, as all teachers will have to meet defined standards, including first-
year teachers who will be more effectively inducted into the teaching profession. Through 
continual renewal of registration every 5 years, teachers will be obliged to attend accredited in-
service  programs  to  update  their  knowledge  and  skills.  A  national  registration  system  for 
teachers will be developed.

C.  Special Features  
47.  The  Project  incorporates  a  number  of  distinctive  features  specifically  targeted  at 
providing systemic support necessary for sustainable improvements in quality of US and PS 
teacher training.  
 
48.  Capacity  Building.  The  Government  will  be  assisted  in  reviewing  current  teacher 
training guidelines and developing a comprehensive framework for teacher development with a 
supporting implementation road map. Institutional capacity will be strengthened by applying the 
accreditation system to teacher training programs, and supporting MOET to create a system for 
registration  of  teachers.  The  outlining  of  the  skills,  knowledge,  and  attributes  required  for 
different levels of excellence among teachers, through creation of teacher profiles, will place 
Viet Nam among the leading nations in innovative teacher development strategies. An improved 
EMIS,  to  include  a  TMIS,  will  be  developed  to  strengthen  planning  and  management  of 
education in general, and teacher development in particular.  
 
49.  Quality Improvement. The focus of the Project is on improving the quality of preservice 
and in-service teacher training. To ensure that the intended improvements occur, reconstructed 
training  programs  will  be  designed  and  regulatory  mechanisms  introduced  to  monitor 
implementation. New initiatives to improve teacher quality include (i) a demonstrable alignment 
of training methods with declared national education goals; (ii) an accreditation process to 
ensure quality of all training courses; (iii) registration processes for all teachers; (iv) formalized 
support programs for first-year teachers; and (v) international training partnerships to improve 
teacher  training  pedagogy,  producing  US  and  PS  students  with  nationally  needed  skills, 
knowledge, and creativity. 
 
50.  Information  Technology.  The  Project  promotes  basic  information  technology 
competencies  for  all  teachers;  all  teacher  trainees  will  be  certified  to  use  key  information 
technology programs and equipment. As technology’s reach expands, teachers are expected to 
be able to maximize the use of technology as a learning tool. 
 
51.  Improved Links with Industry. Through the expansion of industry-TTI partnerships and 
through industry involvement in accrediting selected teacher training courses to meet industry 
needs, the relevance of US and PS to support national development goals will be enhanced.

improved  bridging  programs  with  relevant  support  materials  will  be  offered;  student 
accommodation will be provided on selected campuses; and scholarships will be offered to 
ethnic minority students, particularly girls, to pursue teaching as a career.

IV.   PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 
A.  Benefits 
 
68.  The  Project  will  have  substantial  benefits  for  the  education  sector,  in  particular  for 
secondary education. The systemic benefits to the sector will accrue from (i) a comprehensive 
policy framework for teacher development; (ii) strengthening of the accreditation system to 
ensure the quality of teacher training programs; (iii) a teacher registration system; (iv) improved 
capacity for planning and management of education through the development of an EMIS and 
TMIS, including piloting a program for developing teacher profiles; (v) enhanced capacity of 
institutions responsible for training US and PS teachers; and (vi) overall improved quality of 
teachers.  
 
69.  The secondary education subsector will benefit specifically from the Project. All TTIs will 
benefit  from  improved  curriculum  and  pedagogy.  Seventeen  TTIs  will  receive  support  to 
modernize and expand instructional facilities and equipment, so that in preservice and in-service 
programs teachers are trained to provide improved quality secondary education, both in content 
and  methodology.  This  will  result  in  a  better  qualified  student  cohort  for  entering  higher 
education, undertaking further training, or joining the workforce. The demand for better quality 
education is created not only by Viet Nam’s declared national development goals, but also by 
the expanding economy and needs of industry, business, and the service sectors for more 
informed and skilled workers. To develop the creative problem-solving skills demanded by 
employers for international competitiveness, teaching practices will shift from a focus on rote 
learning  to  active  student-centered  approaches,  preparing  them  to  add  value  to  the 
effectiveness of the businesses and organizations that subsequently employ them. To ensure 
that  curriculum  revisions  adequately  reflect  the  diverse  demands,  the  Project  will  hold 
consultations  with  stakeholders  such  as  industry,  teacher  groups,  potential  students,  and 
community representatives wherever appropriate prior to curriculum revision. 
 
70.  The Project will lead to an improved, better managed, and more efficient teacher training 
system. By creating connectivity between institutions and establishing a standardized course 
accreditation process, efficiencies will result and synergies realized through the sharing of best 
practices. Efficiencies will also be achieved centrally as new management procedures are 
developed that allow data, currently stored in many places and thus difficult to access, to be 
reorganized and made accessible through the establishment of an efficient EMIS. As with all 
education systems, the loss of young teachers from the profession is a constant concern. This 
loss has many causes and is very costly, both economically and socially. Through the provision 
of a standardized high-quality support program for all first-year teachers, the resignation rate of 
beginning teachers is expected to decrease.  
 
71.  The direct beneficiaries of the Project will be current and future US and PS teachers who 
will have continuing opportunities to improve their professional competencies through improved 
preservice  and  in-service  training  programs.  The  Project-initiated  improvement  in  their 
professional development will better ensure that all US and PS students are provided with a 
school  experience  that  contributes  to  life  choice,  employability,  reduction  of  poverty,  and 
achievement of national development goals. The indirect beneficiaries will be current and future 
US and PS students who will benefit from instruction from a better qualified teaching force. 
 
72.  Investments in education also have substantial benefits to society. Improved teaching 
quality leads to better education attainment, which in turn leads to higher human productivity, 
greater employability, and overall better opportunities from higher incomes. As more students

18  
complete  relevant  US  or  PS,  their  knowledge  and  skills  are  absorbed  by  the  community, 
increasing  its  capacity  to  improve  social  conditions  for  all.  The  provision  of  highly  skilled 
teachers is central to the process of enhancing community skills and knowledge. An economic 
analysis is attached as Appendix 9. 
 
73.  Through increased support for ethnic minority groups, particularly women, educational 
benefits  will  accrue  to  these  communities  through  greater  educational  success  by  ethnic 
minority teachers. This will also serve as an incentive to increase the percentage of ethnic 
minority  students  to  complete  secondary  education.  Increased  access  for  ethnic  minority 
students will help reduce current disparities between ethnic minority groups and the general 
population, promoting greater social equity and cohesiveness. Four thousand ethnic minority 
students, at least half of whom will be women, will benefit directly through scholarships to 
pursue teacher training. With increased education, income-earning capacity will rise and gains 
to society will accrue through improved indicators of social development. A social poverty 
impact analysis is in Appendix 10, and a gender and ethnic minority development plan in 
Appendix 11.  
B.  Environment and Social Safeguards  
 
74.  The  Project  will  involve  upgrading  and  rehabilitating  existing  TTI  facilities,  with  no 
negative environmental or resettlement impact. No land acquisition or resettlement is required. 
Some new classrooms will be added to existing TTIs, but on land already owned by the TTIs. 
C.  Risks  
75.  The  Project  is  designed  in  support  the  Government’s  strong  commitment  and  high 
priority to improving education to achieve its economic goals. Therefore, the Government will 
continue to support efforts to improve the quality of education, of which teacher education is a 
key concern. The Project was prepared with extensive consultations with government and TTIs, 
which agree on and support proposals contained in the Project. However, several areas of 
concern could affect project performance and outputs. The risks identified occur within the 
context  where  the  size  and  scope  of  the  Project,  involving  31  TTIs  with  17  identified  for 
upgrading  of  facilities  including  five  for  improvement  as  lead  universities,  give  the  Project 
considerable  complexity  and  magnitude.  A  summary  of  risks  and mitigating  circumstances 
follows. 
 
76.  Management Capacity. The major project risk emanates from the number of institutions 
to be supported by the Project by a combination of hardware and software inputs that will 
require considerable PMU management capacity to ensure project inputs within the time lines 
and resources outlined. The Project mitigates this risk by requiring that the PMU and beneficiary 
TTIs establish coordination committees to regularly monitor progress and take timely measures 
to address bottlenecks and delays. Experience indicates that weak management capacity can 
also result in delays in the provision of software. The Project mitigates this risk by providing an 
international  expert  to  be  located  within  the  PMU  to  assist  with  project  management  and 
implementation issues.  
 
77.  Policy Formulation. Any faltering of commitment to review difficult and complex policy 
issues related to teacher development, including recruitment, deployment, standardization of 
qualifications,  and  career  development,  will  impact  policy  formulation.  However,  the 
Government is strongly committed to improving education quality, and supports the review of 
existing policy statements and development of a comprehensive policy framework.

78.  Sustainability.  Expansion  of  institutional  facilities  and  creation  of  information 
management systems to support education and teacher management will require postproject 
operation and maintenance costs. Adequate budgetary provision will need to be made to ensure 
maximization  of  benefits  through  properly  maintained  facilities  and  updated  databases. 
Additional resources will be needed for periodic upgrading of training curriculum and in-service 
training, as determined by the policy review. The Project will generate continuing additional 
incremental costs of $1.5 million annually after the Project. A number of commitments, however, 
will terminate at the end of the Project, and hence will not be an ongoing burden on the budget. 
The most important ongoing financial commitments will be in meeting the base costs of annual 
supplies, materials, power, etc. required to support the operation of the additional facilities and 
equipment provided under the loan, and their continuing maintenance expenses. Given the size 
of the annual operation and maintenance component of the education budget, of more than 
$250 million equivalent,8 the continuing liability would add less than 0.6% annually to the total. 
This is feasible and sustainable, given the Government’s commitment to educational expansion 
and development.  
V.  ASSURANCES 
A.  Specific Assurances 
79.  In addition to the standard assurances, the Government has given the following specific 
assurances, which are incorporated in the legal documents:  
(i)  The Government will provide counterpart funds for project implementation on 
time.  The  Government  will  make  timely  submission  of  annual  budgetary 
appropriation requests and ensure prompt disbursement of appropriated funds 
during each year of project implementation. 
(ii)  MOET will create a project website to disclose information about various matters 
on the Project, including procurements related to the Project. With regard to 
procurement, the website will include information on, among others, the list of 
participating  bidders,  name  of  the  winning  bidder,  basic  details  on  bidding 
procedures adopted, amount of contract awarded, and the list of goods/services 
procured. 
(iii)  In order to develop new curriculum content, pedagogical guidelines, and contract 
teaching  requirements  for  pedagogical  courses,  MOET  will  contract  with 
appropriate providers to develop the courses and will ensure that these courses 
are consistent with the guidelines developed and issued by MOET.

MOET will ensure that the Project is carried out in accordance with the gender 
strategy contained in the Gender Action Plan that has been prepared and agreed 
between the Government and ADB. Specifically, the Borrower and MOET will 
ensure that under Component 2 (b), priority is given to girls from ethnic minorities 
with the aim being that girls receive at least 50% of the scholarships. MOET will 
include in its annual reports to ADB details about information dissemination and 
any  other  efforts  being  made  to  achieve  a  50%  scholarship  ratio  for  ethnic 
minority girls. 
(v)  The  Government  will  ensure  that  Project  is  prepared  and  implemented  in

the quality and access to US and PS teacher development received by the ethnic

SECTOR AND SUBSECTOR ANALYSIS 
 
1.  The national education and training system is all-encompassing, ranging from nursery 
school to the highest doctoral programs, and from formal schooling and training to nonformal 
and continuing education. It comprises 5 years of primary; 4 years of lower secondary; and 3 or 
4 years when students attend either upper secondary (US) (3 years) or professional secondary 
(PS) (3 to 4 years), or attend separately run vocational training institutes for 1 to 3 years. 
Education administration is shared by the central, provincial, and district governments, and 
communes, with central decision making and decentralized implementation. The great majority 
of  formal  education  and  training  is  publicly  provided  through  state–run  schools,  colleges, 
universities, and training centers. However, a small number of nonpublic institutions operate, 
especially schools and preschools. The Ministry of Education and Training (MOET) has overall 
responsibility for education and training, but while it manages higher education institutions, the 
provinces manage US and PS schools; and cities, districts, and communes manage lower 
secondary, primary, and preschool education. The Ministry of Labor, Invalids, and Social Affairs 
has  specific  responsibilities  for  vocational  training.  This  pattern  is  not  uniform  across  the 
country, especially as the policy of promoting greater decentralization of management and fund-
raising in the public sector takes effect. 
 
2.  During the last 10 years, the number of students enrolled in public schools has been 
increasing.  Primary  education  is  nearly  universal,  with  a  net  enrollment  rate  at  97%.  The 
secondary  participation  rate  is  rapidly  expanding  with  the  lower  secondary  education  rate 
targeted  to  reach  90%  by  2010.  Two  strands  of  formal  education  available  after  lower 
secondary,  US  and  PS,  are  usually  conducted  in  separate  schools  by  separately  trained 
teachers, and are managed by the provinces under the aegis of MOET. US is the much larger, 
academically focused stream accounting for 86% of enrollments; while PS is more practical and 
vocationally  oriented  accounting  for  14%  (the  Government  is  taking  steps  to  increase  PS 
enrollment). Both can lead to university and college entry, and enrollments in both are growing rapidly.  
 
3.  While enrollments in US and PS are increasing at much the same rate, the same cannot 
be said for two key ingredients in their provision, namely, the number of schools and the number 
of teachers. In neither strand has the growth in the number of schools kept up with the increase 
in student enrollment. The number of US schools almost doubled during 1995/96 to 2003/04, 
the number of PS schools in 2003/04 was almost the same as in 1995/96. Teacher numbers 
kept pace with student numbers in US, but grew only sluggishly in PS.  
 
4.  The enrollment rate for US increased an average of 12% per year between 1995–1996 
and 2003–2004, but is predicted to fall from a high of 14.61% in 2005 to 4.79% in 2010. For PS, 
increases averaged 11% per year between 1995–1996 and 2003–2004, with a 4.9% increase in 
2005. Enrollments are projected to rise to 14.6% in 2010. Official figures indicate that enrollment 
trends showed sharp increases in the latter half of the previous decade, but declined in the early 
years of this decade; most of the growth since the mid 1990s has been in the US, PS, and 
postsecondary education subsectors. In fact the higher the level of education, the sharper the 
enrollment  increase;  this  is  partly  due  to  the  already  high  participation  rates  for  primary 
education. For US and PS, these increases will require an additional 47,824 US teachers and 
10,594 PS teachers to be trained during 2005–2010, an approximately 44% increase in the 
number of teachers required if current student/teacher ratios are to be maintained (Table A2).  
 
5.  Female teachers comprise 56% of US teachers and 45% of PS teachers, however no 
available data breaks down this information by region and field of training. About 97% of US 
teachers are fully qualified, while only 83% of PS teachers are. Mountainous and remote areas

have a shortage of qualified teachers. In highland areas, up to 50% of the teachers have been 
reported to be not fully trained. While ethnic minorities make up 13.75% of the population, only 
3.5% of US teachers are from an ethnic minority. No data is available for PS. 
 
6.  US and PS enrollments are unevenly distributed by household income, ethnic group, 
and urban or rural area. A gap exists between Kinh and Chinese residents groups and ethnic 
minority groups in school enrollment, with the enrollment rates of 45.2% and 19.3%. Children 
from the poorest quintile are enrolled at the rate of only a quarter of the richest quintile. Girls 
and boys in rural areas, where most ethnic minority groups live, are less likely to attend school 
than those in urban areas. The reasons for different enrollment rates include the direct cost and 
opportunity  cost,  low  parental  awareness  of  the  benefits  of  long-term  investment  in  child 
education, and sociocultural obstacles especially the practice of old customs including the early 
marriage of girls.  
 
7.  Enrollment of ethnic minority students has risen sharply, increasing by 60% from 1999 to 
2004.  However,  they  still  remain  underrepresented  at  9.4%  of  total  enrollments  against  a 
population share of 13.7%. Several measures are continuously being applied to facilitate the 
access  of ethnic  minorities  to  higher  education,  including  preparation  in  boarding  schools, 
admission without entrance examinations, lower standards to pass the examinations, offers of 
scholarships, and waiving of tuition fees. Attention is also being given to improving female 
students’ enrollment rates although the gender gap in US enrollments is not significant. 
 
8.  Steady economic growth, with gross domestic product (GDP) growth averaging 7.5% in 
the last decade, and the Government’s strong commitment to education have resulted in public 
expenditure on education claiming a higher percentage of GDP (increased from 3.5% in 1996 to 
an estimated 4.6% in 2004) than any other country in the region except Malaysia and Thailand. 
Expansion of education can also be gauged from the annual increases of over 19% in wages 
and salaries compared with less than 13% annual growth for the pubic sector as a whole. A 
greater proportion of the education budget goes to capital expenditure for US and PS than on 
other subsectors. The majority of funds available for teacher training are public funds, with little 
provided by the private sector. Education is still very centralized, with teacher training the most 
highly centralized subsector.  
 
9.  Quality of education remains a serious concern, particularly in remote and mountainous 
regions.  Surveys  conducted  by  funding  agencies  indicate  the  following  causes:  (i)  limited 
infrastructure, (ii) inaccessibility, (iii) language and culture barriers, (iv) lack of adequate number 
of qualified teachers, and (v) the perception that returns to education are low. Lack of well-
educated youth among ethnic minorities has direct implications not only for poverty reduction 
through lack of employability but also for social issues such as population, health care, human 
resources for local governance, and other community development issues. The Government 
recognizes the need to upgrade the quality of education and increase access for both males 
and females to achieve the development objective of increasing the proportion of the labor force 
that is skilled and trained to 30% by 2005, and to 40% by 2010. In addition professional training 
for youth in rural areas needs to be intensified. The Education Development Strategic Plan for 
2001–2010  specifically  refers  to  the  need  to  improve  the  quality  of  teaching  by  fostering 
innovative  teaching  methods.  The  plan  also  refers  to  the  need  for  quality  assurance  by 
strengthening the accreditation system. The Project supports the major suggestions contained 
in the plan for improving the quality of US and PS by improving the quality of teachers. An 
analysis of the quality and management issues in the education sector is in Supplementary

The human development situation varies considerately across the country (Source: National Center for Social

Poverty: From 5%–10% of the population is estimated to still be vulnerable to falling into poverty. (Source: Poverty

the average rate of poverty was very high at 35.6%, while the rate of urban poverty was much lower at 6.6%. In rural 
areas, poverty and the vulnerability of falling into poverty are more pronounced. This is especially true for some 
remote, disaster-prone mountainous regions that have a high concentration of ethnic minority groups such as the 
northern mountains, especially the North West, Central Highlands, North Central Coast, and South Central Coast 
regions.  
 
The two main better-off urban areas, the Red River Delta and South East regions while having high growth also have 
high poverty densities as a result of increased urbanization. In the rural areas of the North West and North Central 
Coast, poverty density is lower because of the relatively smaller populations. The challenge is to provide appropriate 
support for the poor, both in large cities and rural and mountainous areas.  
 
Ethnic Minority Group Incidence of Poverty. In Viet Nam, 53 ethnic minority groups make up 13.8% of the total 
population. Their situation is complex as many groups are small in number and often confined to a specified location.

Central Highlands, and South Central Coast regions, where ethnic minority groups are more concentrated, the poverty 
rate and vulnerability are highest. The rate of poverty among ethnic minority group households is 69.3% higher than in

GENDER AND ETHNIC MINORITY DEVELOPMENT ACTION PLAN 
 
1.  The  Upper  Secondary  and  Professional  Teacher  Development  Project  supports  the 
Government’s development goals by improving the quality of secondary education through 
extensive support for teacher education for both general upper secondary (US) and professional 
secondary  (PS)  levels.  The  Project  contributes  to  poverty  reduction  by  producing  a  better 
qualified and more productive work force. The Project aims to (i) improve the quality of US and 
PS  preservice  and  in-service  teacher  training;  (ii)  expand  access  to  US  and  PS  teacher 
development;  (iii)  strengthen  capacity  for  planning,  management,  and  delivery  of  teacher 
training for US and PS; and (iv) improve facilities to strengthen instructional capability in teacher 
training institutes. The Project will enhance training quality, efficiency, access and equity, and 
management. The gender action plan (GAP) supports the project objectives, and highlights 
specific actions that will be integrated during implementation. Specific targets will be developed 
further at the start of the Project. The GAP was prepared according to Viet Nam regulations and 
education guidelines, and in accordance with the Asian Development Bank (ADB) Policy on 
Gender and Development (1998). While the Project provides targeted support to increasing 
participation of ethnic minority groups, some additional actions are reflected in the GAP in 
accordance to ADB’s Policy on Indigenous Peoples (1998).   
 
A.  Background 
2.  Secondary education is divided into two subsectors: (i) US provides general education; 
and (ii) PS education has a major focus on technical and vocational training. Appendix 11 
includes  a  gender  analysis  and  Table  A11.1  provides  an  overview  of  ethnic  and  female

B.  Legal  Framework  for  Achieving  Gender  Balance  in  Education  Development  in 
Disadvantaged Areas 
4.  The Government supports conditions, guidelines, and policies for promoting social equity 
and gender equality, and prioritized programs for ethnic minority development to ensure the 
preservation of their diverse cultural identities and languages. The legal framework for ensuring 
equity and gender equality, including access to education and training, is well integrated. For 
instance,  see  the  Comprehensive  Poverty  Reduction  and  Growth  Strategy,  2001–2010; 
Education  Development  Strategy,  2001–2010  (Ministry  of  Education  and  Training,  2001); 
Education for All Plan, 2003; National Strategy for Women Advancement to 2010 (NCFAWS, 
2002); Five-Year Socioeconomic Development Plan, 2006–2010; and draft Gender Equality 
Law (currently being considered by the National Assembly, 2006). 
5.  The  development  objectives  of  the  Comprehensive  Poverty  Reduction  and  Growth 
Strategy  include  (i)  achieving  better  education  for  all,  (ii)  ensuring  gender  equality  and 
empowerment  of  women,  (iii)  reducing  vulnerability,  and  (iv)  eradicating  poverty  while 
preserving the cultural identity of ethnic minority groups. The strategy considers implementation 
of the education plan “with equity and higher quality for all, especially for ethnic minority groups” 
as one of the most important concerns and decisive factors for poverty reduction.  
6.  The Strategy for Education Development for 2001–2010 includes special measures for 
promoting equity, and addressing gender and ethnic minority issues in education and training, 
such as (i) apply measures for reducing the gender gap in access to education and training; (ii) 
work out special incentives for encouraging more women and girls in remote, rural, and ethnic 
minority  areas  to  attend  schools;  and  increase  percentage  of  female  students  in  upper 
education boarding schools; and (iii) overcome gender bias and stereotypes in school textbooks 
to promote more equal opportunities in education and training.  
7.  In achieving the goal of implementing gender equality, women’s advancement, and 
children’s rights and protection within the education and training sector, especially for ethnic 
minority  groups,  the  following  objectives  are  clearly  stated:  (i)  implement  successfully  the 
National Strategy for Women Advancement to 2010; (ii) find the measures for ensuring women’s 
equal access to education, training, and in-service professional skills upgrading; (iii) apply 
incentives to encourage female students in remote rural areas, especially for ethnic minority 
females in US, in boarding schools, colleges, and universities; apply supporting policies for poor 
women/girls in education and training; (iv) include measures for readjusting and overcoming 
sex-disaggregated trends in the field of training and education, integrating gender issues into 
the professional orientation programs and training; and review and improve quality of schools 
textbooks and get rid of old gender perceptions, bias, and stereotypes; (v) apply measures for 
increasing the number of female managers and women in leadership positions in all education 
levels; (vi) create education promotion funds for females, and define the female targets to be 
achieved in all education and training levels and retraining and upgrading skills courses; and 
(vii) strengthen the education, propaganda, and social advocacy for raising awareness and 
responsibilities of state agencies, institutions, households, and individuals for promoting gender 
equality.
